natural problem: There exist constants $p$ and $q$ so that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ the vectors $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c},$ $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c},$ and $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c}$ are always collinear.  Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$
natural solution: The line through $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}$ and $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}$ can be parameterized by \begin{align} &\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} + t((2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) - (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c})) \\
&= (1 + t) \mathbf{a} + (-2 + 5t) \mathbf{b} + (3 - 7t) \mathbf{c}. \end{align}To get an expression of the form $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c},$ we want the coefficient of $\mathbf{a}$ to be 0.
Thus, we take $t = -1,$ which gives us $-7 \mathbf{b} + 10 \mathbf{c}.$  Hence, $(p,q) = \boxed{(-7,10)}.$

fixes a b c :: "'a::real_vector"
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "collinear {a - 2 *\<^sub>R b + 3 *\<^sub>R c, 2 *\<^sub>R a + 3 *\<^sub>R b - 4 *\<^sub>R c, p *\<^sub>R b + q *\<^sub>R c}"
shows  "(p, q) = (-7, 10)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given three collinear vectors, the first vector is formed by subtracting twice the second vector from the first and then adding thrice the third vector, the second vector is formed by adding twice the first vector to thrice the second vector and then subtracting four times the third vector, and the third vector is a linear combination of the second and third vectors with coefficients p and q. Find the values of p and q. The final answer is p = -7 and q = 10.
